facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 5 were duly nominated for election to the House of the People from Hoshangabad Constituency in Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondents 1 to 5 herein were duly nominated for election to the House of the People from the Hoshangabad Constituency in the State of Madhya Pradesh. Respondents 4 and 5 subsequently withdrew from the election, leaving the contest to the other candidates.

facts.text: Respondents 4 and 5 withdrew from the election.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 4 and 5 subsequently withdrew from the election, leaving the contest to the other candidates. At the polling the appellant secured 65,201 votes the first respondent 65,375 votes and the other candidates far less and the Returning Officer accordingly declared the first respondent duly elected.

facts.text: At polling, appellant secured 65,201 votes, first respondent 65,375 votes, Returning Officer declared first respondent elected.

anchor.surface_text: At the polling the appellant secured 65,201 votes the first respondent 65,375 votes and the other candidates far less and the Returning Officer accordingly declared the first respondent duly elected.

facts.text: Appellant filed Election Petition No. 180 of 1952 to set aside election alleging 301 votes for first respondent invalid under Rule 47(1)(c) for lacking distinguishing marks under Rule 28.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed Election Petition No. 180 of 1952 for setting aside the election on the ground inter alia that 301 out of the votes counted in favour of the first respondent were liable to be rejected under Rule 47 1 c of Act No. XLIII of 1951 on the ground that the ballot papers did not have the distinguishing marks prescribed under Rule 28, and that by reason of their improper reception, the result of the election had been materially affected.

facts.text: Rule 28 requires ballot papers for Parliamentary Constituencies to bear green bar.

anchor.surface_text: Under this rule, the Election Commission had decided that the ballot papers for the Parliamentary Constituencies should bear a green bar printed near the left margin, and that those for the State Assembly should bear a brown bar.

facts.text: At polling stations Nos. 316 and 317 in Sobhapur, voters for House of the People given brown bar ballot papers instead of green bar.

anchor.surface_text: What happened in this case was that voters for the House of the People in polling stations Nos. 316 and 317 in Sobhapur were given ballot papers with brown bar intended for the State Assembly, instead of ballot papers with green bar which had to be used for the House of the People.

facts.text: Total votes at those stations: 443, of which 62 for appellant, 301 for first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The total number of votes so polled was 443, out of which 62 were in favour of the appellant, 301 in favour of the first respondent, and the remaining in favour of the other candidates.

facts.text: First respondent contested petition, pleaded Rule 47 directory not mandatory, votes validated by Election Commission.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent contested the petition. He pleaded that the Returning Officer at Sobbapur had rightly accepted the 301 votes, because Rule 47 was directory and not mandatory , and that further the votes had been accepted as valid by the Election Commission, and the defect, if any, had been cured.

facts.text: First respondent filed recrimination petition under section 97 alleging wrong ballot papers at polling station No. 299 Malkajra and No. 371 Bammangaon wrongly rejected, would give him 117 more votes.

anchor.surface_text: He also filed a recrimination petition under section 97 of Act No. XLIII of 1951, and therein pleaded inter alia that at polling station No. 299 at Malkajra and at polling station No. 371 at Bammangaon ballot papers intended for use in the State Legislature election had been wrongly issued to voters to the House of the People by mistake of the polling officers, that all those votes had been wrongly rejected by the Returning Officer, and that if they had been counted, he would have got 117 votes more than the appellant.

facts.text: Election Tribunal majority held Rule 47(1)(c) mandatory but result not materially affected, dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal held by a majority that Rule 47 1 c was mandatory, and that the 301 ballot papers found in the box of the first respondent bearing the wrong mark should not have been counted while the third Member was of the opinion that rule was merely directory, and that the Returning Officer had the power to accept them.

facts.text: Appellant moved High Court of Nagpur under articles 226 and 227 for certiorari to quash Tribunal decision.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the High Court of Nagpur under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of certiorari or other order or direction for quashing the decision of the Election Tribunal on the ground that it was illegal and without jurisdiction.

facts.text: High Court dismissed petition by majority.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was dismissed in accordance with the majority opinion.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under article 132(1).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges, however, granted a certificate under article 132 1 , and that is how this appeal comes before this Court.

facts.text: Appeal heard on December 9, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. December 9.

facts.text: High Court judgment dated 4th November 1953 in Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 174 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 132 1 of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 4th November 1953 of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur in Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 174 of 1953.

facts.text: Returning Officer obtained approval from Election Commission before counting votes with wrong marks.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer at Hoshangabad reported to the Chief Electoral Officer, Madhya Pradesh that wrong ballot papers had been issued owing to the mistake of the polling officers, and obtained the approval of the Commission for their being included, before the votes were counted.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Rule 47(1)(c) mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: (approximate position based on text)

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside election of first respondent and quashed Tribunal and High Court decisions.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal must accordingly be allowed, the decisions of the High Court and the Tribunal quashed and the whole election set aside.

facts.text: No valid election due to recrimination findings.

anchor.surface_text: The combined effect of section 97 and section 100 2 c is that there is no valid election.

facts.text: High Court Bench: Sinha C.J., Mudholkar and Bhutt JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was heard by a Bench consisting of Sinha, C. J., Mudholkar and Bhutt, JJ., who differed in their conclusions.

holdings.text: High Courts have jurisdiction under article 226 to issue writs against decisions of Election Tribunals.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises for decision in this appeal is whether High Courts have jurisdiction under article 226 to issue writs against decisions of Election Tribunals. That article confers on High Courts power to issue appropriate writs to any person or authority within their territorial jurisdiction, in terms absolute and unqualified, and Election Tribunals functioning within the territorial jurisdiction of the High Courts would fall within the sweep of that power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 226 confers absolute power to issue writs to any authority; Election Tribunals fall within territorial jurisdiction; limitation must be from Constitution itself.

holdings.text: Article 329(b) does not bar supervisory jurisdiction under Article 226 over Election Tribunal decisions after election petition is filed.

anchor.surface_text: On a plain reading of the article, what is prohibited therein is the initiation of proceedings for setting aside an election otherwise than by an election petition presented to such authority and in such manner as provided therein. A suit for setting aside an election would be barred under this provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 329(b) bars initiation of proceedings, not post-election petition supervisory review; cites Ponnuswami (original proceedings barred) and Durga Shankar (appellate review allowed).

holdings.text: Writ of certiorari can be issued against Election Tribunal decision even after it becomes functus officio.

anchor.surface_text: it is incapable of exercise for the reason that under the scheme of Act No. XLIII of 1951, the Tribunal is an ad hoc body set up for determination of a particular election petition, that it becomes functus officio when it pronounces its decision,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certiorari to quash targets the record/custodian (s.103), not the tribunal; functus officio irrelevant as writ demolishes order; cites English/American precedents, s.103 custodians amenable.

holdings.text: Election Tribunals are subject to superintendence of High Courts under Article 227.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that the Election Tribunals are subject to the superintendence of the High Courts under article 227 of the Constitution,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Superintendence both judicial and administrative; cites Waryam Singh.

holdings.text: Proper grounds exist for certiorari: Tribunal committed error of law apparent on face of record in s.100(2)(c) enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: Then the question is whether there are proper grounds for the issue of certiorari in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal considered extraneous matters (polling officer mistake, voter intention) beyond valid votes; error manifest; cites Northumberland, Basappa.

holdings.text: Rule 47(1)(c) is mandatory; ballot papers without prescribed distinguishing mark must be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether Rule 47 1 c is mandatory, the argument of Mr. Pathak is that notwithstanding that the rule provides that the Returning Officer shall reject the ballot papers,

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Shall reject' uniform with other sub-rules (a,b,d) mandatory; no degrees of compliance possible; directory would allow unauthorized discretion.

holdings.text: Election Commission approval post-polling does not validate ballot papers lacking prescribed mark under Rule 47(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended that the Election Commission had validated the votes in question, and that in consequence the acceptance of the ballot papers by the Returning Officer under Rule 47 1 c was not open to challenge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Approval condones defect but does not change prescribed mark under Rule 28 pre-polling; Rule 23 requires correct paper at polling time.

holdings.text: Improper reception of 301 votes under Rule 47(1)(c) materially affected election result under s.100(2)(c).

anchor.surface_text: the contention of Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the appellant is that in reaching this conclusion the Tribunal had taken into account matters which are wholly extraneous to an enquiry under section 100 2 c

holdings.reasoning_summary: Result based on valid votes only (Rule 48); cannot count rejected votes or speculate intention; polling mistake (Rule 23) irrelevant to validity.

holdings.text: Combined effect of s.97 recrimination and s.100(2)(c): no valid election; whole election set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The combined effect of section 97 and section 100 2 c is that there is no valid election. Under the circumstances, the proper order to pass is to quash the decision of the Tribunal and remove it out of the way by certiorari under article 226, and to set aside the election of the first respondent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's election also invalid if declared due to recrimination (Rule 23 breaches); neither candidate elected on invalid votes.

holdings.text: Application for certiorari maintainable under Arts 226 and 227.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the application of the appellant for a writ of certiorari and for other reliefs was maintainable under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises for decision in this appeal is whether High Courts have jurisdiction under article 226 to issue writs against decisions of Election Tribunals. That article confers on High Courts power to issue appropriate writs to any person or authority within their territorial jurisdiction, in terms absolute and unqualified, and Election Tribunals functioning within the territorial jurisdiction of the High Courts would fall within the sweep of that power.
This appeal must accordingly be allowed, the decisions of the High Court and the Tribunal quashed and the whole election set aside.
This appeal must accordingly be allowed, the decisions of the High Court and the Tribunal quashed and the whole election set aside.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 on no 329(b) bar to 226 supports broader concept c1 of 226 power.

anchor.surface_text: On a plain reading of the article, what is prohibited therein is the initiation of proceedings for setting aside an election otherwise than by an election petition presented to such authority and in such manner as provided therein. A suit for setting aside an election would be barred under this provision.
This appeal must accordingly be allowed, the decisions of the High Court and the Tribunal quashed and the whole election set aside.

it is incapable of exercise for the reason that under the scheme of Act No. XLIII of 1951, the Tribunal is an ad hoc body set up for determination of a particular election petition, that it becomes functus officio when it pronounces its decision,
